item.title: Best United Miles Redemption Ever? (+ bonus rant)
Odyssey Blend
item.description: Starbucks released a new blend called the Odyssey Blend. To be honest, I bought the coffee because I thought the bag looked nice. It even inspired a silly little design in my bullet journal. Luckily for me, the coffee was reasonably fresh (hard to guarantee at Starbucks b/c of no roast dates). When I brewed the beans, the slurry bloomed quite a bit. The coffee is also roasted surprisingly light, especially compared to other starbucks blends.

item.title: Condorcet's Paradox in Political Science (Part 1)
item.description: The “Condorcet Paradox” in political science observes that even if the preferences of all the individuals in some society are “rational”, the preferences of the group may not be1. Furthermore, the probability that irrational group preferences arise increase as the number of voters and number of policies under consideration become large. I thought this result was rather unintuitive. After all, what’s the point of voting if group preferences are inconsistent a lot of the time?

item.title: Analyzing Politics Review
item.description: General Impressions Recently I’ve been reading a book called “Analyzing Politics” by Kenneth A Shepsle, which introduces rational models in political science. Rational models seek to explain political behavior (e.g. group voting, legislation, etc.) using individuals with “rational preferences”. Because I’ve waded through an economics major, I felt at home with this book’s treatment of the subject. My next few blog posts will cover a few topics I found interesting.

item.title: About
item.description: About Me Hi Everyone! I’m Jason Yang, an Econ/Math grad from The University of Chicago. I’ve produced some (probably mediocre) research in Financial Economics as an Undergrad and follow articles published in top economics and finance research journals. Other than that, I’m also quite interested in applications of math and computation to problems outside of economics. I also roast and brew single origin coffees from around the world and try to take a scientific approach to coffee brewing.

item.title: Local Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
item.description: I was surprised to find a bag of beans from Ethiopia Yirgacheffe roasted yesterday at a local roastery (Kusanya Cafe) at Whole Foods. The beans had a very smooth mouthfeel and were very bright and fruity. I tried V60 first with the tabbed & bleached paper filters. The coffee felt quite thin but definitely not lacking in personality. The Clever Dripper with a cloth filter tasted similar but had a much fuller body (which I personally prefer) because of the additional dissolved oils.

item.title: Nesco Roasting Guide and Review
item.description: I got a great deal on a Nesco roaster ($45 for an open-box product, normally $80) and figured it would be great value at that price. I’ve used this roaster ~50 times, which should be enough to comment a bit on a very simple machine. I’ll update this post as I collect more data and learn new things about the roaster. Pricing If you want to buy a Nesco, you probably won’t have to buy it at full price ($80).
